In favour of the future it may be argued that the more vivid construction, which is also the commonest, is here called for, and that the weak aorist subjunctive is avoided where it resembles the future in form, while the blending of future and subjunctive after  may be easily paralleled. But there are several well-authenticated instances of the sigmatic aorist after  in Demosthenes (cf. below, ii.  2, iii.  2), which have been recklessly altered.

=to make a man hostile, here hostile to Philip, i.e. to rouse them to fight against him. The old reading , here and in iii. 7, is impossible,  being an intrans. verb (to be at war), which cannot govern an external acc. Perhaps the confusion arises, in the case of these verbs and of , from the fact that the present participles of both verbs have the same form.

, as the outcome of personal grievances.  is more commonly used, with an acc., of the person against whom the grievance is felt: but as strained relations imply two parties, it may be used with reference to the aggrieved as well. The verb  is mostly used of legal accusations, the noun  mostly of general complaints or grounds of complaint.
, by reason of their present fears and their past experiences. Philip had in 351 made an attack on Olynthus, and was now (349) threatening the whole Olynthian confederacy.

. In 358 Athens wrested Euboea from the Thebans, who had held it since the battle of Leuctra (371): it was in 358 or 357 that Philip besieged Amphipolis, and foiled the embassy here mentioned by positively declaring that he would hand the city over to Athens when taken.
. For the frequent use of prepositions denoting motion with verbs denoting rest, see L. and S. , C. 2, , I. 2.
, not you would have gained (), but you would have been in possession of. So  is of showing continuous zeal, though had shown is all that we can say in English.
, trouble.
To Pydna (357) the Athenians seem to have sent no help at all; to Potidaea (356), Methone (353), and Pagasae (352) they sent too late.

[], if retained, spoils the whole section, in which Demosthenes is walking with great caution over thin ice, in referring to the uses of the Theoric Fund (for which see note on iii.  11). With studied vagueness he says, Money you have, but you take (i.e. spend) it according to your own tastes. With  retained, these last words become a direct reproof, after which  is absurd. And Demosthenes would scarcely be so fatuous as to say, Far be it from me to propose that the military fund should be a military fund.

. These words do not clash with , because  is strongly opposed to . In effect: I  it the right course, I admit, but you  insist on spending the money your own way: then why should I make a useless proposal?
, literally that there should be one and the same regulation for taking money and doing one's duty, i.e. that only those who perform military service should get money from the state.

marks a real proposal. But it is only made in order to force the people to the course which Demosthenes dare not himself propose. He passes on hastily from the hated  to the general conclusion .

, perhaps it may be too hard a saying, but . . . This is said to be the only instance in the orators of  introducing an independent cautious assertion. Plato is very fond of this construction, in which the idea of actual fear is never present, nor is a verb of fearing understood before . We have here the original deprecatory force of , let it not. In a writer like Plato this  has become simply a suggestion put politely, and with a delicate irony (Thompson, ).

, puts forth the blossoms of hope, literally blossoms on hopes. The whole metaphor has a parallel in Shakespeare, , Act iii. Sc. 2:

p: This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth The tender leaves of hope, to-morrow blossoms, And bears his blushing honours thick upon him: The third day comes a frost, a killing frost.

. . . . A good example of the Greek use of co-ordinate clauses, where we should make the four main verbs in the  clauses subordinate. They say, I wonder that you did indeed resist, &c. (as we know that you did), but that now . . . where surprise is not expressed at the resistance, but at the subsequent slackness in face of previous resistance. In English, That, whereas you resisted, &c. you now. . . .

. This refers to the war taken up in 378 B.C. by Athens and Thebes. The independent rights of Greek cities, which had been secured in 387, had been constantly violated by Sparta, notably when she seized the Acropolis of Thebes in 383.

Moreover,  below shows clearly that  is used in a general sense of prizes of war.  was probably inserted by a copyist or commentator who was not equal to giving more than the most literal meaning to .

, emphatic, opposed to . In the war with Philip the generals and soldiers run all the risks, and  would get all the prizes of success: in their self-sought wars, they run fewer risks and get considerable profit.

, the result is, literally it remains over. The preposition in this verb (as in , &c.) has its less usual force (like the Epic  with gen.) of beyond, exceeding. Thus  is (1) to surpass, with gen., (2) to remain over, whether as a survival or as a consequence.

. Demosthenes here metaphorically applies the rules for tax-collecting to party politics. When a certain  was needed in 377 B.C., it was arranged that henceforth it should be collected from four classes, graduated in wealth, with a  (head) and an  (superintendent) attached to each. The highest class numbered the 300 most wealthy citizens, the second more (less wealthy), the third more still, and the fourth most of all. [L. and S. are wrong in speaking of the 1200 most wealthy citizens: this applies only to the extension of  to the trierarchy, which took place in 357 B.C.an arrangement with which, though prior to this speech, we are not concerned here.] Applying this system to the state of the two political parties, Demosthenes says that each party has a  (corresponding to the ) and a  (corr. to the ). The  defends the  (e.g. Chares) in the assembly. And each side has its noisy partisans (corresponding, very inaccurately, it must be confessed, to the 300 wealthiest citizens). Translate: For in former times you were divided into partnerships for paying the war-tax: now you are divided into partnerships for playing the politician.

, and the resources of the Phocians are exhausted. The primary idea of  in post-Homeric times is to say . . . not. Hence it came to mean (1) to forbid; (2) to renounce (literally to say that you will have nothing to do with); (3) intrans., to faint, fail (literally to say that you cannot). The connection of (2) and (3) may be seen from the trans. and intrans. uses of to give up in English.

. A number of jurymen (we do not know how many) were yearly chosen to form a board to deal with changes in the laws. As such an appointment at the regular time could not be , we must assume either that Demosthenes proposes the establishment of an extra board, or that no election had taken place for the last year at least. The latter view is probable: it seems inconceivable that Demosthenes should not have said appoint  board of , if one was at this time sitting.

p.#text: . The people had now come to regard as their right the dole which Pericles had first given them as a favour, and the surplus of yearly expenditure was now regularly paid into the Theoric Fund. It seems probable that Eubulus, at some time between 354 and 350, had passed laws () forbidding the alienation of this fund. Hence, in i.  19, Demosthenes only dares to hint at the nature of his proposal, and even here demands that the authors of the laws shall themselves incur the odium of repealing them. One Apollodorus (probably in 348) was fined by the law courts for actually passing such a proposal through the Senate and Assembly, and it was not till 339 that Demosthenes carried the day.
, to speak quite plainly.  is idiomatically added for emphasis (probably with an accompanying gesture) to certain adverbs, especially  and . Thus, , just outright; , quite easily.

, malingerers; literally those who will not form  up along with the rest, i.e. join the army. The rendering disorderly (L. and S.) makes no sense; Demosthenes is complaining that certain classes or individuals are exempted from service.

, some one to propose. The generalising use of the article with participle. So , any chance-comer; , any one who wishes. Cf. ii. 1,  (note).

. This refers no doubt to the loss of civil rights, not to the penalty of death. Any one who might propose the appropriation of the Theoric Fund would be indicted on a , or action for proposing illegal measures, as Apollodorus was afterwards: and this offence was punished, not by death, but by a fine. Until this was paid, the person found guilty would be , and from a political point of view, .

. Inscriptions clearly show that forms like , &c., are far later than Attic. About the end of the second century B.C.  began to supplant  in many words, mainly verbs, and as manuscripts were being largely multiplied at Alexandria at that period, many such barbaric forms have been perpetuated until our own time. Cf. note on , ii. 21.

. Although the races under Philip's rule at this time were mainly non-Hellenic, both Herodotus and Thucydides assert the Grecian descent of the reigning house. Both Alexander I. (some 130 years before) and Philip himself, in 356, had been allowed to compete, and had been victorious, in the Olympian games. But Macedon had held such slight intercourse with the Greek states that the bitter taunt is perhaps half justified; and the fact that Philip was a  (cf. i.  5) would settle the question with the members of a free Greek state.
. . . Isn't heanything you like to call him? i.e. no name can be too bad.

, and may it bring good luck. This was a formula used to preface decrees, and in ordinary life as a pious wish when any new step was being taken.

is not the speaker's fault, literally not now, as it was in the case of . Dr. Sandys sums up well the sense of : Do not blame your advisers, but follow the best advice, however unpalatable it may prove.

p: (1.) To the attack made on the two territories in 458, and on Megara by Pericles in 431.
(2.) To recent invasions of which we know nothing, though in Speech 13 (not written by Demosthenes) there is an incidental mention of an attack on the Megarid.
(3.) To neighbouring Greek states taken at random.
Probably (2) is correct. If Demosthenes had been thinking definitely of events 100 years old, he would have stated the facts more particularly.

See Index of Proper Names. A special instance of public spirit on the part of Aristides may be found in the warning given to his enemy, Themistocles, before Salamis (Her. viii. 79), and on the part of Pericles in his brave defiance of the Athenians, when they clamoured to go out from the city against the Spartans who were ravaging their estates (Thuc. ii. 21-22). Nicias was nothing if not conscientious; the earlier Demosthenes we only know as a vigorous and capable general.

. A very partial statement of the case. However willing the allies were to join the league originally, they constantly revolted throughout the period, and were one after another, with the exception of Chios and Lesbos, reduced to the condition of subjects.

. It is absurd to speak of the shifty Perdiccas II. as having been subject to the Athenians. He played fast and loose with Athens from the beginning of the war till his death, and, though entering into agreements with her more than once, did considerably more service to her enemies.

p.#text: . The war is that undertaken in 378 by the Athenians and Botians jointly against Sparta. In the same year Athens formed her second maritime league.

, have had your sinews ripped out. The metaphor is strange to English, and we can scarcely do justice to the idea of moral deterioration implied in the loss of fibre. It is highly improbable that sinews of war are meant, though this view has met with some support owing to the next words (.).

, celebrate the procession of the Boedromia. This festival was held on the 6th day of the month  (about September 26), in honour of Apollo  (Helper in battle), and Artemis the Huntress. It commemorated a mythical Athenian victory, but whether that gained by Theseus over the Amazons or by Erectheus over Eumolpus is uncertain. There is a curious reading  given for  by ancient citers of Demosthenes: it is probably due to a copyist who did not understand the above use of .

here furnishes one of the few instances of an optative following a primary verb ( understood from ).
